Natalie Peterson, Data and Evaluation Assistant, referred to the most recent official poverty report from the United States Census Office. Data on income and poverty in the United States were released in September 2018 and 2017 data reports. According to the report, some 39.7 million people were living in poverty in the United States in 2017. Of this group, 17 million were non-Hispanic whites. This means that non-Spanish whites make up 42 per cent of all people living in poverty. It also referred to the 2017 Poverty Supplemental Measure. This is a broader measure of poverty in the United States, as Peterson said. It includes persons living together and not related, including unmarried partners, and has a broader definition of what is described as income, including general non-monetary benefits such as food stamps and medical aid. After that, we asked Peterson about the section of the 2012 Census Bureau presentation we found while looking for evidence that 70% of people living in poverty are white. The slide is entitled "Are most people in poverty white?" According to the slides, which look at the 1960 - 2011 data, 31.7 million whites were living in poverty at the end of the time period under study. This compares with 14.5 million non-white people. This means that about 69 percent of people living in poverty were white. But Peterson noted a warning: "White," in this case, includes Hispanics who know their race as white. Given the historical data in the official poverty report, 46.2 million people of all races were living in poverty in 2011. Of that group, 67% of all people living in poverty were "white alone." However, given "white alone, not Spanish," the percentage of people living in poverty fell to 41 per cent. In 2017, out of 39.7 million people living in poverty, 26.4 million were "white alone," or about 66 per cent, while those who were "white alone, not of Spanish origin" were 42 per cent. Our Facebook ad claims that 70% of Americans living in poverty are white. Among them are persons of Spanish origin, which is close: in 2017, the last year for which data are available, 66 per cent of the people living in poverty were whites, including Hispanics. However, this figure falls to 42 per cent - under the official poverty measure - when persons of Spanish origin are eliminated. This Facebook post, published by a Facebook account called "Fed Up Dispables," shows people with seemingly poor integrity in rural environments. There is also a quote from Bernie Sanders, given by Sanders in response to a discussion question in 2016 without Lemon from CNN about "ethnic blind spots." His answer distinguishes white Americans from colored people. Therefore, while there is contextual evidence that this article is intended to give the impression that 70% of people living in poverty are not colored humans, accurate reading of the claim leaves enough room for vibration to exclude the fact that demographers sometimes use the word "white" to include those who describe themselves as Hispanic. Because that depends on whether "white" includes those of Spanish origin, we value Facebook's claim that whites represent 70% of Americans living in poverty.
